content: I've added the constraint N â‰  0.
I've updated the description. I hope it's clearer now. Let me know if it's not.

I know the puzzle has been approved already but I think the statement lacks clarity and would benefit from an update.

A user didn't understand the "repeat" part of the encoding processus. Maybe it can be clarified.

Could have been nice if tests followed the theme too (aliens). But I guess it's too late.

I don't understand why N can be negative since it represents the number of times the message was transformed. I think it's too late too.

I've edited to copy the first test to the first validator, on grounds that it breaks the symmetry of NOT HAVING SPACES in the message, that is  statemently correct, yet very misleading. (former case: "e texts a i hthisimpl"

I think having both encode and decode shifts it slightly more on the "puzzle" side of the scale.

Still a very easy one; my solution is deliberately as brutal as it gets barring "bogodecode".

Why not a CoC?
Darn, I did not see that you have to encode AND to decode.

This puzzle isn't very difficult, but it does require some careful thinking. I solved it without calculating anything related to triangular numbers. Just encode the string once anyway to get the parameters required and then decode using those parameters.

I've edited the puzzle to make the wording clearer. I haven't changed it to a clash of code, but it's ok to change it to one.
Also changed a "transformed" instance to "encoded" to further eliminate ambiguity (both encoding and decoding *are* a transformation)

I've exchanged the "multiple decoding" test and validator on grounds that the input ENDS IN A MEANINGFUL SPACE in the validator.

It's probably going to be problematic to some anyway, but at least now it's out in the open.
